There are night when life changes.  Nights that you know you will remember for the rest of your life.

Thursday 20th April 2006 is now one of those nights.

It's probably going to come as little surprise to anyone reading this who knows me well that Pearl Jam at the London Astoria was the best gig I've ever seen in my life.......by a longshot.  I haven't ever smiled from ear to ear for a whole two hours at a gig ever.  I haven't ever experienced a massive headrush when a band has walked on stage before.  I haven't ever cried during a gig before.  I haven't ever got chills multiple times throughout a bands performance.

Gen and I reached the Astoria about 6 o'clock after a meal, which I really didn;t feel like eating cos I felt like i was going to puke with excitment.  There were mad scenes outside....about 60 ticketless fans stood about on the corner, some with signs begging for tickets.  We got talking to a bunch of folk in the queue who were really cool, two gay guys from Aberdeen, a couple from Newcastle and a guy from Essex, all of whom had shelled out the big bucks on ebay for their tickets (To be honest, I can't imagine anyone of them felt they'd been ripped off by the end of the night).  Got into the Astoria about 7.30....we stood by the bar to the right of sounddesk.  Theres this little raised area with a banister that you can stand against and we managed to get on the second row there so had an amazing view of the stage...totally on a level with it.  Just above us on the side of the balcony we could see Robert Plant from Led Zeppelin sat with his son.

The Astoria was rammed....I'm sure there were more than the 1600 capacity in there.  Folk were streaming in right up until the lights went out at 8 o'clock and a deafening roar went up.  My head felt like it was about to explode.  I didn't think we'd ever make it to this moment...it was unreal.  PJ came on, Eddie had that mischeivous, wild eyed look in his eyes, like Gen's nephew gets when you give him a piece of chocolate.  They started with World Wide Suicide and continued like this:

'World Wide Suicide' 
'Life Wasted' 
'Severed Hand' 
'Unemployable' 
'Gone' 
'Even Flow' 
'Sad' 
'I Am Mine' 
'Insignificance' 
'Army Reserve' 
'Present Tense' 
'Better Man' 
'Marker In The Sand' 
'Do The Evolution' 
'Why Go'

*Encore break*

'Man Of The Hour' 
'Given To Fly' 
'Elderly Woman Behind The Counter In A Small Town' 
'Porch'

*Encore break*

'Comatose' 
'Leavin' Here' 
'Yellow Ledbetter'

*mini Encore break*

'Alive'

The first batch of new songs sounded ace but when Even Flow kicked off, it was incredible.  It was at this point that the girls stood in front of us against the banister decided to give up the best view in the house and relinquish it to us which was a real stroke of good luck.  During Betterman, Ed let the crowd sing the whole first verse and chorus, responding with a "that was nice".  Why Go was great as a main set closer.  I was really happy they did Given To Fly as it's my favourite PJ song but it was Elderly Woman which raised the bar even further.  Such an emotional moment, this was the song which made me cry......I'll never be able to listen to it again without getting a bit choked up I don't think.  Then to follow that with an absolutely blistering rendition of Porch was breathtaking.

Comatose was introduced as a "fucker of song to sing so we leave it till the end".  They turned the houselights on for Yellow Ledbetter as they usually do which was great, such a lovely song.  I think everyone thought that was going to be it...me included.  YLB is a traditional closer for them and I think that was the original intention.  Stone had already left the stage but Ed was waving him back.  The cheer that went up as they returned was like none I've ever heard at a gig.  For about 5 second before what can only be decsribed as a deafening roar greeted the opening riff of Alive.  The place went mental....you couldn't hear Eddie over the crowd for the whole song.  It was a 10 minute version which culminated in Mike McCready playing his guitar over the back of his head on stage left while stage right, no more than 20 feet away from us, Ed was swinging the mic furiously in the air.

So much energy was on that stage, way more than they show on any of the DVDs or at Manchester six years ago.  There was a 5 minute ovation at the end and I think they would have gone on except that there was a curfew and Ed had nearly finished his wine.

Gigs like this don't happen everyday, they don't happen every year.  I don't think I'll ever witness anything like it again and that from now on gigs will just be good nights out rather than anything really special.  You could spend the rest of your life going to a gig every single night and not see anything a hundreth as special and amazing as Pearl Jam were at the Astoria.

I hope I can get to see them again this year.  I think it's going to be within the next week if any more shows are to be announced, though it seems any shows on mainland Britain except Reading and Leeds are looking doubtful now.  Theres a show in Dublin two days before Leeds so Gen and I may go over for that.

Gen loved every minute of it too.  I'd been a bit worried she might not but she says they're her new favourite band now and that it was the best she'd ever seen...even better than Radiohead.

Back in reality.....saw the Arctic Monkeys last night who were very cool too.  I was still thinking about Thusrday and was kinda knackered so was quite thankful for the seats in Newport Centre (weirdest venue ever).  But they were cool....kinda had a similar vibe to seeing Oasis 10 or 12 years ago.

Saw Panic! at the Disco on Wednesday who were kinda crap really. The album is so original but their live show was like seeing Funeral for a Friend without the enregy.  Plus the crowd were complete wankers.

Had a fun weekend in Glasgow last week.  Was great to see Lisa and Chris again and catch up with them, it was a lot of fun.  Gavs baby is lush, she looks just like him.  Good to see the G-man again too as always.  The Ben Kweller gig was okay.  He was quite good though a little under rehersed. .......so anyway, that was 2005, come and gone, a fairly big year for me on the whole.  I'm going to indulge myself now and do some geeky end of year type reviewing stuff, starting with....

MUSIC

I don't really think 2005 have been a vintage year for albums.  There's been some good records but compared to 2004 when there were just so many great albums out, it's been a bit on the poor side.  Funeral for a Friend, Death Can for Cutie, Idlewild all released records which were fine but didn't live up to their initial promise.

On the plus side, Nine Inch Nails, Weezer, My Awesome Compilation, Motion City Soundtrack, Alkaline Trio all brought out above average records.  The Oceansize album was a massive step forward for them, a much more confident, assured and all round better piece of work.  and Fall Out Boy released a cracking second album which should see them throw off the silly emo tag if theres any justice in the world

BUT, my album of the year goes to the only record that had me playing it on repeat for a couple of weeks solid, and that was Dopamine's debut album Auditioning My Escape Plan.  It's not a spectacular record and it doesn't do anything that lots of bands haven't done before but for me, this was the most enjoyable album of the year.

.....if I had to pick the best album I;d actually bought this year, it'd be De Ja Entendu by Brand New but thats like a couple of years old so doesn't count.

looking to the future, 2006 promises to deliver a whole lot more.  I'm already looking forward to new albums from Arctic Monkeys, Muse, Taking Back Sunday, Dashboard Confessional, Hundred Reasons, Lost Prophets, Orko, Sucioperro, Brigade, Snow Patrol, Biffy Clyro, Brand New and last but hopefully not least, the best band on the entire planet, Pearl Jam


GIGS or MUSIC IN THE LIVE ENVIRONMENT.

There were two gigs this year that really battled it out for my favourite gig of the year.  The one that narrowly missed out was Nine Inch Nails incredible show at Glasgow's Barrowlands in July but taking the prize was the gig by the band who are arguably the best live band today......Green Day at Glasgow's SECC.  2 hours of pure pop punk fun, played by folk who looked like they were genuinely enjoying what they're doing up there.

Other notable gigs worth mentioning this year were Biffy at the Carling Academy which was a crowning achievement, Faithless at Cardiff Arena, Foo Fighters at the Millenium Stadium and Hundred Reasons at Cardiff Barfly.


TV

There has been so much good TV in 2005.  Although I didn't discover it on TV, Alias has become one of my favourite shows ever!!  24 was as reliable as ever too.  But for me, there's been two shows which have stood out this year.  The first was the return of Dr Who which was everything I could have hoped for.  The Buffy influence over the show was for me it's winning aspect and the next series look to be ever better.

In a way we have Dr Who to thank for delivering the other stand out TV show of the year.  If Dr Who hadn't been such a huge success, do you really think Lost would have been given the promotion and slot it was by Channel 4.  I don't, I think it would have been on at 11 o'clock on a Sunday night and then buried in the early hours of the morning, just like they did with Angel.

But thank god it wasn't.  I've already written loads about Lost in this journal and everyone reading it knows it rocks so there is nothing more to say right now.


MOVIES

and finally in this little list of retropects, the movies of 2006.  Lots of dissapointments along the way, War of the Worlds, Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory, Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire but lots of amazing stuff too.

The Machinist was incredible, Closer was the best written film of the year, Serenity kicked so much ass, almost as much as Sin City, King Kong delivered in spades and George Lucas finally gave us the Star Wars movie we'd been hoping he'd make.  But my movie of 2005 goes to the only film I've been to the cinema to see twice for quite some time.  It was so good it made me cry.....it was Batman Begins.


2005 was a big year of change for me.  I've had three different homes in the last 12 months, a whole new job and in a whole new country.  I can;t say it's all been easy because it hasn't, but things seem to be calming down now after a fairly turbulent 12 months for me and I'm feeling good about where I am.  I'm hoping 2006 is going to be more of year to enjoy where I m rather than trying to get there.  It seems like almost everyone I know has had a year where pretty big stuff has happened to them. People have either got engaged, got pregnant or bought houses or sometimes a combination of those 3.

There's a good few days, memories which will stay with me from this year, the New York trip for just being a really spectacular week, moving in to the house and getting all our furniture and stuff, as well as a good few nights out which have been a lot of fun too: the Orko/Laeto show in freezing Glasgow in January, the curry party in August etc.

and on that note, it's time to stop being so mushy and reflective and begin the new year with a much needed shower.
